choices.text: Fracture of the fourth or fifth metacarpal bone
A separation of the extension expansion over the middle interphalangeal joint
Compression of the deep ulnar nerve by dislocation of the lunate bone
Avulsion fracture of the dorsum of the distal phalanx

questions.text: A 34-year-old woman is admitted to the hospital after a car collision. Physical examination reveals a mallet finger. Which of the following conditions is expected to be present during radiographic examination?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Exp: Mallet finger, also known as baseball finger, is a deformity in which the finger will be permanently flexed at the distal interphalangeal joint, due to avulsion of the insertion of the extensor tendon at the distal phalanx.

questions.text: A 56-year-old woman is admitted to the hospital after a severe car crash. A large portion of her chest wall needed to be surgically removed and replaced with a Musculo-osseous scapular graft involving the medial border of the scapula. Which of the following arteries will most likely recompensate the blood supply to the entire scapula?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Exp:  The suprascapular artery arises as a major branch of the thyrocervical trunk from the subclavian artery. It has rich anastomoses with the circumflex scapular artery and could provide essential blood supply to the scapula. The dorsal scapular artery would be lost with the graft. None of the other vessels listed is in position to provide adequate supply to the scapula.

questions.text: A 48-year-old woman who has had a stroke complains of weakness of her right arm and weakness of her right lower face. Language assessment reveals the following speech deficits: slow, labored speech; dysarthric, telegraphic speech; usually good comprehension; and poor repetition. Which of the following types of aphasia do these neurologic findings describe best?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Exp: Key features that point to motor aphasia are slow, labored dysarthric telegraphic speech; relatively good speech comprehension; poor repetition; frequent depression; and frequent buccolingual dyspraxia. Motor aphasia is also called Broca, expressive, and anterior aphasia.

questions.text: A male pt. who is married with a child from his wife's previous marriage, presents with inability to have a child in common. He has h/o chronic lower respiratory infections. What does the physician suspect?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Exp:

Individuals with primary ciliary dyskinesia commonly have recurrent respiratory infections if the cilia are unable to clear the respiratory epithelium of microorganisms, debris, and so forth.

Examination of the patient’s ejaculate probably show that he has viable but nonmotile spermatozoa, which is caused by a genetic defect resulting in cilia with axonemes that lack ciliary dynein arms and thus are unable to beat.

choices.text: Proximal portion of the lacrimal nerve
Zygomatic branch of the facial nerve

questions.text: A 22-year-old patient has dryness of the corneal surface of his eye because of a lack of tears. Which of the following nerves may be damaged?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Exp:  The secretomotor fibers to the lacrimal gland are parasympathetic fibers that run in the facial, greater petrosal, Vidian (nerve of the pterygoid canal), maxillary, zygomatic (of maxillary), zygomaticotemporal, and lacrimal (terminal portion) nerves. The lesser petrosal nerve carries secretomotor (preganglionic parasympathetic) fibers to the parotid gland. The deep petrosal nerve contains postganglionic sympathetic fibers. The zygomatic branch of the facial nerve supplies the facial muscles.

questions.text: The drummer presents with hearing loss. Otoscopic examination reveals loss of contraction of the tensor tympani and the stapedius, which prevents damage to the eardrum and middle ear ossicles. These muscles are most likely controlled by which of the following nerves?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Trigeminal and facial nerves

Exp: The tensor tympani is innervated by the trigeminal nerve, and the stapedius is innervated by the facial nerve.

choices.text: Cochlear implants is the first choice for Hearing rehabilitation
Stapedotomy will be the part of treatment protocol.
Osteogenesis imperfecta can lead to a similar CT appearance but is far more common in the temporal bone
Bisphosphonates will be of no use in stabilising hearing in cochlear cases.

questions.text: A 54-year-old patient with complaints of recent dizziness and progressive, bilateral sensorineural hearing loss with onset in adolescent age.She complains of increasing hearing loss for over 15 years. Her audiogram is shown as follows, She also undergoes computed tomography (CT) scanning of the temporal bones. The scans are shown as follows.Choose the most appropriate statement regarding the diagnosis :
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Stapedotomy will be the part of treatment protocol.

Ref: Read the text below    

Sol:

•    The diagnosis is otosclerosis with cochlear involvement or fenestral and cochlear otosclerosis. The ‘double ring’ sign around the cochlea on CT is typical of this disease. 

•    Osteogenesis imperfecta can lead to a similar CT appearance but is far less common in the temporal bone.

•    Various drug treatment strategies have been proposed for stabilising hearing with inner-ear involvement. There are several studies (although relatively low grade) suggesting that fuoride treatment may slow the progression of sensorineural hearing loss, although the dosage and treatment duration is very heterogenous in these studies. 

•    More recently, bisphosphonates, particularly third-generation bisphosphonates, such as zoledronate or risedronate, have been suggested to be useful in stabilising hearing as well. 

•    Hearing rehabilitation options always include standard hearing aids. In this case, consideration should strongly be given to stapedotomy to close the air-bone gap followed by hearing aids. 

•    This would allow much better function with the hearing aids. The third option is cochlear implantation. At this level of hearing, this might well be considered if hearing is not satisfactory with hearing aids even after stapedotomy or stapedectomy.

questions.text: A female presented with long standing nasal obstruction. She also complaints about comments from her friends telling about foul smell coming from her nose which she could not recognise. On evaluation, atrophic rhinitis is diagnosed. What can be the etiology in this patient to develop secondary atrophic rhinitis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Chronic sinusitis

Ref: Read the text below

Sol:  

•    Specific infections like syphilis, lupus, leprosy, and rhinoscleroma may cause destruction of the nasal structures leading to atrophic changes. 

•    Atrophic rhinitis can also result from long-standing purulent sinusitis, radiotherapy to nose or excessive surgical removal of turbinates. 

•    Extreme deviation of nasal septum may be accompanied by atrophic rhinitis on the wider side.

questions.text: Which of the following part of cochlear implant is implanted in scala tympani during surgery:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Electrode array

Ref: Read the text below    

Sol:

Receiver/Stimulator (Implanted under the skin) and Electrode array (implanted in the scala tympani of the cochlea) are the part of internal component of cochlear implant, which are fitted inside the body.

questions.text: A case of carcinoma larynx with the involvement of Left vocal cord, left aryepiglottic fold, left ventricular band and invading into paraglottic space. Which of the following statements is true for the managements of this case?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Total Laryngectomy and radiotherapy

Ref: Read the text below

Sol:

•    This is the stage T3 of cancer larynx as there is involvement of paraglottic space. 

•    Therefore total laryngectomy and radiotherapy is required in this case.

questions.text: A 5 year old boy while having dinner suddenly becomes aphonic and is brought to the casualty for the complaint of respiratory difficult. What should be the appropriate management?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D)

questions.text: A patient presented with a 3.5-cm size lymph node enlargement, which was hard and present in the submandibular region. Examination of the head and neck did not yield any lesion. Which of the following Investigations should follow?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Triple endoscopy

Ref: Read the text below

Sol:  

•    Suspected lymph node may have metastases from the upper aero digestive tract. 

•    Since no lesion is found on physical examination of head and neck,triple endoscopy would be justified next. 

•    Supravital staining helps in selecting the site of biopsy in a lesion,as no lesion is discovered, it will not be very useful.

questions.text: All of the following conditions are associated with snoring except:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Laryngeal papillomatosis

Ref: Read the text below

Sol:  

•    Snoring occurs due to nasal, nasopharyngeal or oropharyngeal obstruction. 

•    Multiple laryngeal papillomatosis causes stridor and respiratory distress.

choices.text: Examination of pharynx shows a midline bulge on posterior pharyngeal wall
Mostly presents as a pediatric airway emergency
Results of suppuration of lymph nodes.
It extends from skull base to bifurcation of trachea

questions.text: A 12-year-old previously healthy child  presented to the emergency department with fever, throat pain, and difficulty breathing. The previous history was unremarkable, except for perforated appendicitis 15 months prior. One week prior to admission, the patient reported the symptom of a sore throat that improved slightly after 2 days of self-prescribed penicillin. However, a worsening sore throat returned the day prior to admission. In the ED, the patient was found to have a right-sided sore throat, pain while swallowing, odynophagia, poor oral (p.o.) intake, right neck tenderness, and a fever of 40.1°C. The patient also reported a recent development of trismus and muffled “hot potato” voice. X-Ray demonstrate soft tissue swelling posterior to the pharynx, with a widening of the prevertebral soft tissue. All of the following are true about diagnosis except
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Examination of pharynx shows a midline bulge on posterior pharyngeal wall

Ref: Read the text below

Sol:

Retropharyngeal Space - Between the buccopharyngeal fascia covering the pharyngeal constrictor  & the prevertebral fascia

* Extends from base of skull to bifurcation of trachea

* Divided by a fibrous raphe into 2 (spaces of Gilette)

* Abscess causes U/L bulge on post pharyngeal wall

Acute retropharyngeal abscess - Commonly seen in children < 3yrs

* Results of suppuration of retropharyngeal LN

* In adults - from penetrating injury of post. pharyngeal wall

C/F :    * Dysphagia & difficulty in breathing (prominent symp)

* Stridor & croupy cough

* Torticollis

* Bulge in post. Pharyngeal wall (usually seen on one side of midline)

Xray STN lat. view - widening of prevertebral shadow

T/t - I & D without GA, antibiotics

questions.text: Paroxysmal sneezing on getting up early in morning from bed is associated with ?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Vasomotor rhinitis

Ref: Read the text below

Sol:  

Vasomotor Rhinitis

  • It is a non allergic rhinitis clinically simulating nasal allergy.

Symptoms

  • Paroxysmal sneezing : Bouts of sneezing start just after getting out of the bed in the morning. 
  • Excessive rhinorrhoea : This accompanies sneezing and may be the only predominant symptom. It is profuse and watery and may even wet several handkerchiefs. The nose may drip when the patient leans forward, and this may need to be differentiated from CSF rhinorrhoea.
  • Nasal obstruction : This alternates from side to side. Usually more marked at night. It is the dependent side of nose which is often blocked when lying on one side.
  • Postnasal drip.

questions.text: Symptoms and signs of foreign bodies at different levels depend on the area of involvement. Palpatory thud, audible snap is seen in
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Tracheal foreign body

Ref: Read the text below

Sol:                

•    A foreign body in trachea may move up and down the trachea between the carnia and the undersurface of vocal cords causing "audible slap" and "palpatory thud'.

Symptoms and signs of foreign bodies at different levels

choices.text: Parasympathetic nerves supplying the sinoatrial node
Parasympathetic nerves supplying the atrioventricular node
Sympathetic nerves supplying the sinoatrial node
Sympathetic nerves supplying the atrioventricular node

questions.text:
A 22-year-old female college student comes to the hospital OPD complaining of palpitations. The patient has had occasional incidences of rapid heart rates but never lasting for more than 2 minutes. In this instance, the heart rate has been elevated for 15 minutes. The patient has only been sleeping 4 hours a night while studying for examinations and is consuming “more than the usual amount” of coffee to help her remain alert. ECG shows ventricular tachycardia, characterized by narrow QRS complexes at a rate of 180/min. Atrial P waves are also present at a rate of 180/min, but the QRS complexes precede the P wave.
Carotid sinus massage causes pulse rate to abruptly decrease to 80 beats/min. This effect is due to activation of which of the following?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Parasympathetic nerves supplying the atrioventricular node

This is a patient of supraventricular tachycardia, with the origin of the electrical impulse being within the AV node, rather than the SA node, as indicated by QRS copexes preceding the P wave. 
Paroxysmal super ventricular tachycardia occurs when the origin of the tachycardia is in the atria or the AV node (“above” the ventricles, or “supraventricular”). One possibility is the occurrence of a re-entry loop of depolarization within the AV node (AV nodal re-entrant tachycardia). In this instance, a wave of depolarization originating in the atria is split within the node and a portion flows retrogradely in the node until it encounters tissue outside its refractory period. The circuit then becomes self-propagating. Because the electrical impulse arises within the AV node it spreads through the ventricles following the normal conducting pathway. Consequently, the QRS complexes appear normal. In contrast, the tachycardia of ventricular origin would be due to an ectopic pacemaker developing within the ventricles and likely be characterized by an abnormally wide QRS complex. The origin of the electrical impulse within the AV node, rather than the SA node, alters the relationship between the P wave and the QRS complex. For this patient, the ventricles have completely depolarized before the wave of depolarization retrogradely excites the atria. Consequently, the QRS complex precedes the P wave in the electrocardiogram. 

The area of carotid arteries near the bifurcation is massaged, stimulating the stretch receptors in the carotid sinus. The increase in vagal activity slows the conduction in the atrioventricular node, breaking the abnormal conduction circuit.

choices.text: Aortic arch and carotid body chemoreceptors but not central chemoreceptors

questions.text: A 55-year-old man comes to the clinic complaining of fatigue and persistent shortness of breath, which becomes worse during exercise. He has a history of respiratory infections and has a chronic cough that is worse in the morning. The patient has smoked cigarettes since he was a teenager; currently he estimates smoking one pack of cigarettes a day. He is in mild respiratory distress, with an elevated respiratory rate and shallow breaths. An end-expiratory wheeze is heard on auscultation. This patient’s chest radiograph is normal and arterial blood gases are PO2 75 mm Hg, PCO2 42 mm Hg, and pH 7.32. In this patient, ventilation is being stimulated by afferent inputs from which of the following structures?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Aortic arch and carotid body chemoreceptors but not central chemoreceptors
This is a patient of COPD. 

Carotid and aortic body chemoreceptors are stimulated by decrease in Po2 and increase in Pco2 but the central or medullary chemoreceptors respond only to increase in Pco2.

Normally, ventilation is controlled by CO2 levels as sensed by the arterial chemoreceptors and the central chemoreceptors. The increase in ventilatory drive is a reflection in part of the elevation in Pco2. Over time, however, the respiratory acidosis is partially compensated by the renal retention of HCO3. In addition, CO2 drive in the central nervous system is also attenuated by HCO3 transport into the cerebrospinal fluid. These compensations blunt or completely remove the CO2 stimulation of ventilation. As the disease progresses, arterial Po2 levels fall below 60 mm Hg. Hypoxia, sensed by the arterial chemoreceptors- aortic and carotid body chemoreceptors but not the central chemoreceptors, become the primary ventilatory drive. In this instance, placing the patient on supplemental inspired oxygen can cause respiration to stop.

choices.text: Increased sympathetic activity, increased heart rate, increased peripheral resistance
Increased sympathetic activity, decreased heart rate, decreased peripheral resistance
Increased sympathetic activity, increased heart rate, decreased peripheral resistance
Increased sympathetic activity, decreased heart rate, increased peripheral resistance

questions.text: A 22-year-old man enters the hospital emergency department after severing a major artery in a motorcycle accident. It is estimated that he has lost approximately 700mL of blood. His blood pressure id 90/50 mm Hg. Which set of changes would be expected in response to hemorrhage in this man?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Increased sympathetic activity, increased heart rate, increased peripheral resistance
Loss of blood volume leads to decreased stretch of the vessel walls which in turn causes decreased baroreceptor stimulation resulting in increased sympathetic and decreased parasympathetic activity, resulting in increased heart rate and peripheral resistance.

questions.text: A new seizure drug is being investigated that binds to and activates GABA-A receptors in the CNS. During their experiments, a researcher uses a micro electrode to measure the RMP of a neuron. He records RMP of -70mV. Which of the following membrane potentials is likely to be recorded following exposure to the drug?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

-75mV

GABA-A receptors are ionotropic receptors which cause opening of chloride channels, leading to hyperpolarization of the cell. GABA-A agonist will, therefore, cause the RMP of the cell to become more negative or -75mV.

questions.text: A 75-year-old man gives a history of having worked in factory where asbestos was used as an insulator. He worked in this factory for a period of five years in his early 40s. He now has severe shortness of breath. His chest physician diagnoses him as a case of asbestosis. Which of the following flow-volume loops will be typically seen in this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Loop D

In restrictive lung disease parenchymal, such as asbestosis, lung volumes are reduced. TLC, RV, FVC are decreased. PEFR and MEFR are relatively less affected. The expiratory curve is typically tall and narrow.

questions.text: A clinical experiment is conducted in which one group is given 50gms of glucose i/v and another group is given 50gms of glucose orally. Which of the following can explain why the oral glucose load is cleared from the blood at a faster rate compared with the i/v glucose load?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

GLP- induced insulin release

GLP-1 secreted by the L cells is k/a physiologic beta cell stimulating hormone of GI tract. It stimulates the release of Insulin by beta cells of pancreas. This effect will not be seen after i/v glucose.

questions.text: A Sindhi couple is seeking genetic counselling for an inherited anemia, although both of them do not have any anemia, but the blood investigations show microcytic hypochromic picture. HPLC finding of husband is HbA 92%, HbA2 7%, HbF1% and wife HbA-94.5%, HbA2 4.5% HbF 1%. What is the likely hood of them having a child born with inherited anemia?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

25%. Husband and wife both are thalassemia carriers by their HbA2 levels thus the chance of child having a disease is 25%.

questions.text: 33-year-old woman has experienced low grade fevers, night sweats, and generalized malaise for the past 2 months. On physical examination she has non-tender cervical and supraclavicular lymphadenopathy. A cervical lymph node biopsy is performed. On microscopic examination at high magnification there are occasional CD15+ and CD30+ Reed-Sternberg cells along with large and small lymphocytes and bands of fibrosis. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Nodular sclerosis Hodgkin Lymphoma

Reed-Sternberg cells are multinucleated with large nucleoli which are positive for CD15 and Cd30. Presence of fibrosis (collagen bundle) gives rise to diagnosis of nodular sclerosis Hodgkin lymphoma.

questions.text: A 32-year female presents with tinnitus. Further examination revealed a mass in the cerebellopontine angle. Family history suggests her father also had similar tumor which was resected surgically and is doing well after that. Histological examination from the tumor is as follows what is the likely diagnosis and most likely mutation leading to such familial tumor?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Schwannoma;NF2. 

The histology is showing classical verocay bodies (nuclei free areas due to palisading of nucleus, which is seen in Schwannoma. It can be associated with inherited NF2 mutations.

choices.text: Inability to arrest the cell cycle at G1S

questions.text: A 52-year-old man has had increasing fatigue for the past 6 months. On physical examination he has a palpable spleen tip. Laboratory studies show a WBC count of 189,000/microliter. The peripheral blood smear shows many mature and immature myeloid cells present. Cytogenetic analysis of cells obtained via bone marrow aspiration reveals a t(9:22) translocation. Which of the following cellular mechanism would lead to neoplasm in this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

An increased tyrosine kinase activity. 

T9;22 leads to increased production of tyrosine kinase in the cells leading to increased proliferation. Tyrosine kinase inhibitors are used in treatment of such neoplasms.

choices.text: An increased IgE secretion after drug administration

questions.text: A 10-year child presents with rhinitis and fever. Examination showed temperature of 101 F, the nasal mucosa is red and there is an increased secretion. He was prescribed with Aspirin by the local physician. After consuming aspirin the child develops breathless ness, however the temperature is 98 F. Which of the following could have lead above mentioned side effects?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Increased Leucotrine. Aspirin inhibits COX pathway thus enhances metabolism by LOX, Leucotrines are metabolites of LOX, Leucotrine C4 D4 E4 cause bronchoconstriction that causes breathlessness, this is clinically called as NSAID induced asthma.

questions.text: An 8-month-old infant is admitted to pediatric ward due to bacterial pneumonia for the fifth time. He also had a bout of otitis media. The infant is irritable, has poor feeding and had an episode of seizures few days back. The child’s jaw muscle undergo spastic contraction when jaw was tapped. Serum immunoglobulins were normal. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

DiGeorge Syndrome. Recurrent infection with hypocalcemia (suggested by spastic contraction of jaw and seizures) makes a diagnosis of Di George Syndrome.

questions.text: An 8 year child presents with abdominal pain. The pain is located to the right hypochondrium. The pain is colicky and disappears after few minutes. An ultrasound shows gall stones, and a shrunken spleen. Rest of physical examination is normal. A peripheral blood examination showed abnormal shaped RBC and you start suspecting a genetic disease. Which of the following is true about this child?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

An inherited qualitative hemoglobinopathy. The child is having gallstones + abnormal shaped RBC + shrunken spleen is suggestive of sickle cell anemia which is a quantitative hemoglobinopathy.

questions.text: A 2-days old infant has extensive crying and not passed meconium. A radiological imaging was done with barium which is as shown in the image. A biopsy was taken from narrowed segment, and the dilated segment proximal to the narrow segment. Which of the following is likely finding on the biopsy?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

This is a patient of Hirschprung disease .In Hirschprung disease there is absent ganglion cells which leads to failure of relaxation of the colon( constricted part), leading to obstruction. To overcome this obstruction there will be hypertrophy of nerve bundles proximal to obstruction.

questions.text: A 35 year old is diagnosed to have an inherited disease due to mutation of HFE gene. Which of the following is not the likely manifestation of this disease?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Type II DM. HFE mutation is seen in primary hemochromatosis which will have type I DM due to destruction of islet cells not type II DM. other manifestation includes malabsorption syndromes, cirrhosis, synovitis.

choices.text: Reduced ANP due to cardiac lesion
Excessive ANP due to cardiac lesions

questions.text: A 32 year old male presents with reduced urine output for last 24 hours. He has not history of pharyngitis or pyoderma in the past month, he has no history of any major surgical procedures except he underwent extraction of third molar 1 month back. BP is 140/90, pulse is 90/min. Auscultation of heart shows a murmur in the mitral area. Urine examination shows 10 RBC/HPF and a few RBC casts. Which of the following mechanism would have led to such a manifestation in this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Circulating immune complex. The patient is having a nephrotic syndrome (hypertension oliguria and hematuria) in addition has a cardiac murmur and has a history of dental procedure ( which is a risk factor for infective endocarditis by streptococcus viridians in the oral mucosa) the patient is most likely having a subacute infective endocarditis which has led to immune complex formation leading to post streptococcal glomerulonephritis.

questions.text: A patient presents with bleeding per rectum and colonoscopy shows a polypoid growth of 2 cm in diameter. An excision biopsy was done and histology is as shown in the image. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Villous adenomas are sessile adenomas. And have a high risk of malignancy.

questions.text: A 6 year child has a sore throat runny nose low grade fever and malaise. He was prescribed with antihistaminic and NSAIDs and sent home. He continues to take the drugs for a week time and feeling better. On day eight he has swelling in his both wrists and is unable to move. Clinically the wrists are tender for which the physician increased the NSAID dose and sent home again. Three days later presents with vomiting of blood and pain in the abdomen. CBC shows Hb 13g/dL, TLC 10000/cu.mm, platelet count 190000/cu.mm. Physical examination is as shown in the image. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Henoch-Schnolien purpura. Patient is having purpura but platelet count is normal thus B & D are ruled out. The patient is having joint involvement and vessel involvement suggests an immune complex disease which is HSP.

questions.text: A 65 year old retired industrial worker presents with increasing dyspnoea, cough. The lung volumes show FEV1 is reduced and FVC is low. A bronchiolo alveolar lavage shows the following, what is the likely diagnsosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Asbestosis. 

The image shows dumbbell shaped Asbestos bodies seen in asbestosis. Option A and C will have granulomas option D will present as obstructive lunf disease not like restrictive as given in the patient.

choices.text: Using CPD blood instead of ACD blood.

questions.text: A 35-year-old road traffic accident patient has developed severe anaphylaxis after an uncrossmatched emergency blood transfusion. The intensivist successfully treats the reaction and now he requires another blood unit to be transfused because of his severely depleted haemoglobin. Which of the following methods will reduce the chance of similar reaction in subsequent transfusion
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Saline washing of RBC. Anaphylaxis is due to passively adsorbed antigens on the RBC surface from donors plasma, which can be reduced by saline washing of RBC. Crossmatching can prevent haemolytic transfusion reaction not anaphylaxis and allergy. Irradiation of RBC will help to prevent Graft Vs host disease.

choices.text: Increased glucose receptors in tumour cells
Rapid anaerobic glycolysis in tumour cells

questions.text: A 64-year-old male presents with fever and weight loss. Clinical examination is unremarkable except for splenomegaly. A FDG-PET scan was performed in this patient thre were multiple retroperitoneal and mediastinal nodes having an increased uptake. Biopsy from one of them showed a high grade non Hodgkin lymphoma. Which of the following is the reason for increased uptake by the lymphnodes.
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Increased glucose receptors in tumour cells. Increased FDG uptake is due to Warburg effect leading to increased glucose receptors on the tumour cells.

choices.text: Blood is the specimen of choice for detection of poisons
Urine is suitable for single direct spot test
The concentration of poisons found in urine is important in evaluating the quantity ingested or the toxicity.
Levels of drugs in the muscle more accurately reflect blood levels than the liver or kidney.

questions.text: Which amongst the following is not true?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

The presence or absence of poison in urine is important to determine the poison/ toxin ingested. The concentration of poison in urine is not a reliable method to determine the quantity ingested or the toxicity.

choices.text: Wounds numbered 1 and 2 are stab wounds by iron rod
Wounds numbered 1 and 2 are entry and exit wounds by rifled weapon respectively
Wound numbered 1 is stab wound by iron rod and wound numbered 2 is entry wound of rifled weapon
Wounds numbered 1 and 2 are entry and exit wounds by smooth bored weapon respectively

questions.text: A patient is brought to casualty in a state of shock. On examination there is a circular wound (Numbered 1) on front of right side of chest, size 1 cm X 1cm, 3 cm from midline with reddish abraded margins. Hairs around the wound are burnt and brownish in appearance. On further examination another circular wound (Numbered 2) of size 1.5 cm X 1.5 cm with everted margins, is found on the back of right side of chest. Which of the following statements is correct about the underlying wound?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

The presence of a circular wound with burnt hair (singeing) shows entry wound of firearm as the same will not be seen in stab wound. The margins of the second wound are everted outside and it corresponds to the injury number 1, hence it is most likely to be an exit wound.

questions.text: Which amongst the following are the features of female skull?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

In females, parietal bones are prominent, Mastoid tip is narrow and there are round orbits. Cephalic index is used to determine race.

questions.text: A 40-year-old man presents with lesions on his neck that he finds cosmetically unattractive. On examination of the neck, multiple lesions that seem to be hanging off the skin are shown in the image. Each lesion is small, soft, and pedunculated. The largest lesion is about 4 mm in diameter. Most likely diagnosis is?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Acrochordons

Sol:     

• These lesions are skin tags, more formally known as acrochordons.

• They are very common benign lesions that can occur at any skin site, but have a predilection for the neck, axilla, and groin.

• Multiple lesions are common, and the lesions tend to increase in number with age. They are usually asymptomatic but can be irritating.

• Microscopically, an acrochordon consists of a fibrovascular core, sometimes also with fat cells, covered by an unremarkable epidermis.

• Asymptomatic skin tags are usually not treated. Many methods can be used to remove disfiguring or irritated skin tags, including freezing with liquid nitrogen, light electrodesiccation, or excision with scalpel or scissors.

questions.text: A 40 year old farmer presents with lesions on his forearm(shown in image). Colony of the organism on special stain is also shown below.What is the diagnosis ?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Sporotrichosis

Sol :  

• Sporotrichosis is seen in farmers following penetrating injury by plant product(thorn). It is also known as Rose Gardener’s disease.

• It presents as subcutaneous nodules which may break down to form ulcers.

• Asteroid bodies of Sporothrix is shown in the image in question

questions.text: A 6 year old boy presents with asymptomatic lesions on dorsal aspect of hands and genitals as shown in image.What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Lichen nitidus

Sol :  

• Lichen nitidus presents as multiple grouped pinhead sized shiny papules mainly in children. Cause unknown. Sites-genitals, arms. 

• Biopsy has a “claw clutching a ball” appearance. Usually self limiting. 

• Topical steroids and tacrolimus may be used.

questions.text: A patient suffered from Covid-19 infection with severe symptoms. He recovered and is now presenting with complaints of severe hair loss.  The time that is expected to elapse between fever and hair loss is about?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

3 months

Sol :  

  • Basically you are being asked the duration of onset of hair loss in Telogen Effluvium 
  • Understanding the pathophysiology of telogen effluvium requires knowledge of the hair growth cycle. 
  • All hair has a growth phase, termed Anagen, and a resting phase, Telogen. On the scalp, anagen lasts approximately 3 years, while telogen lasts roughly 3 months. 
  • The transition phase between is called catagen which lasts for roughly 3 weeks.
  • During telogen, the resting hair remains in the follicle until it is pushed out by growth of a new anagen hair.

questions.text: A patient presents with diffuse infiltration of ear lobes, face bilaterally. He also had multiple erythematous infiltrated plaques distributed symmetrically on trunk and extremities. He soon develops painful nodules on extremities with fever and chills. Diagnosis is-
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

LL with type 2 reaction

Sol: 

• In LL, papules and nodules usually have normal skin color but sometimes are erythematous with a bilaterally symmetrical distribution on face, arms, legs and buttocks. In polar LL, diffuse infiltration and gradual thickening of the dermis may precede nodulation by months or years. 

• Type 2 (ENL) reactions occur in patients with multibacillary disease (LL and BL). Attacks are often acute at first, but may be prolonged or recurrent over several years and eventually quiet but insidious, especially in the eye. ENL manifests most commonly as painful red nodules on the face and extensor surfaces of limbs. 

• The lesions may be superficial or deep, with suppuration, ulceration. ENL is a systemic disorder producing fever and malaise and may be accompanied by uveitis, dactylitis, arthritis, neuritis, lymphadenitis, myositis and orchitis.

questions.text: A 55-year-old man presents with fever, chills, fatigue, cough, sore throat, and breathlessness for the past 7 days. He describes the cough as productive and says he is fatigued all the time. He says he is a farmer with daily contact with rabbits, horses, sheep, pigeons, and chickens and reports cleaning the barn 3 days before his symptoms started. The patient denies any history of tick bites. Past medical history is irrelevant. His temperature is 39.40C, pulse is 110/min, and respirations are 26/min. On physical examination, there are decreased breath sounds on the right side. A large tender node is palpable in the right axilla. A chest radiograph reveals multiple homogenous opacities in the lower lobe of the right lung and a right-sided pleural effusions. Gram staining of a sputum sample is negative for any organism. Serology tests are negative. Which of the following is the most likely causative organism for this patient‘s condition?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Francisella tularensis

•    This patient has respiratory or pneumonic tularemia, also known as 'rabbit fever‘, zoonotic disease caused by Francisella tularensis, a gram—negative, non—spore forming intracellular pathogen. 

•    The bacterium multiplies within macrophages and primarily targets organs like the lymph nodes, lungs, spleen, kidneys, and liver. 

•    It can be transmitted to humans through arthropod bites, direct contact with infected animals, infectious animal tissues or ﬂuids, ingestion of contaminated food or water or by inhalation of aerosols.

•    In this case, the patient might have acquired the bacterium by inhaling aerosols from a rabbit carcass or excrement Symptoms include high-grade fever. Cough, chest pain, and dyspnea and the onset of symptoms typically occurs 3 to 5 days after infection.

choices.text: Acute exacerbation of chronic HBV infection

questions.text:
A 28-year-old man presents to the ofﬁce with complaints of malaise. anorexia, and vomiting for the past 2 weeks. He also says that his urine is dark. The past medical history is unremarkable. The temperature is 36.80C , the pulse is 72/min, the blood pressure is 118/63 mm Hg and the respiratory rate is 15/min. The physical examination reveals a slightly enlarged, tender liver. No edema or spider angiomas are noted. Laboratory testing showed the following: 

•    HBsAg - Positive 

•    lgM anti-HBc <1:1,000 

•    Anti-HBs -Negative 

•    HBeAg - Positive 

•    Anti HBe - Positive 

•    HBV DNA 2.65 x 109 IU/L 

•    Alpha-fetoprotein 125 ngm 

What is the most likely cause of this patient's condition?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Acute exacerbation of chronic HBV infection

•    Chronic hepatitis B with an acute ﬂare (CHB—AF) is difﬁcult to distinguish from acute hepatitis B (AHB) because CHB-AF and AHB share many similar clinical and iaboratory features. 

•    It is imperative to differentiate between CHE-AF and AHB due to different prognoses and therapeutic strategies. The majority of patients with AHB will recover spontaneously, thus only requiring supportive care. 

•    In contrast, patients with CHB-AF usually require pharmacologic treatment because the hepatocellular dysfunction may lead to hepatic decompensation. 

•    Despite the similarities between CHE-AF and AHB. there are significant differences with respect to clinical. biochemical. and virologic features between AHB and CHE-AF.

•    AHB is characterized as follows: 

o    anti-HBc lgM titer > 1:1,000 or > 10, — HBV DNA 4: 0.5 nmL, AFP level < 100 ng/mL, negative HBeAg. negative anti—HBe, and negative HBsAg.

questions.text: A 54-years old man presents with fever and a painful jaw mass with a yellowish discharge as shown in the image. He says that the jaw mass onset 6 weeks ago and has been progressively increasing in size. He reports a history of chronic alcoholism and 8 currently takes more than 6 drinks daily. His temperature is 31.9°C. On physical examination, there is a 7 x 7 cm mass at the tip of the jaw bone with signiﬁcant surrounding edema and sclerosis. The mass is severely tender to even light palpation and is draining a yellowish malodorous discharge. Oral cavity shows, signs of very poor dentition. Laboratory analysis of the discharge reveals gram positive anaerobic ﬁlamentous bacteria. Which of the following organisms is the as most likely cause of this patient's condition?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Actinomyces israelii.

•    Actinomycosis is a bacterial infection caused by a ﬁfilamentous, gram—positive anaerobic bacteria called Actinomyces israelii. 

•    Most common presenting symptoms include cervicofacial. thoracic and abdominal lesions. 

•    Pelvic actinomycosis is possible in some female patients. 

•    The characteristic finding is a suppurative granulomatous inflammation with formation of a draining abscess or sinus tract that may discharge yellowish sulfur granules.

•    Actinomycetes are part of the normal flora of the oral cavity and can cause chronic cellulitis of the face. 

•    Poor oral hygiene is one of the risk factors for this infection. Penicillin G is the drug of choice for the treatment of infections caused by Actinomyces israelii.

questions.text: A 34—year-old man presents with acute onset seizures and hallucinations. The patient's wife says that he had been on a camping trip to United states a few months earlier to study bats as apart of his research project, but otherwise has not travelled recently. Past medical history is signiﬁcant for hypertension, managed medically with hydralazine and enalapril. The patient's condition rapidly deteriorates, and he passes away. An autopsy is performed and a histologic stained section of the brain is shown in the image. Which of the following receptors are targeted by the pathogen most likely responsible for this patient's a condition?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Acetylcholine receptor

•    This patient most likely has rabies. which can be transmitted by bats and dogs. Patients who have been bitten by these animals should receive a post-exposure regimen of human rabies immunoglobulin and 4 doses of rabies vaccines on days 0, 3, 7, and 14 (Cat III bite). 

•    If untreated, patients may develop the paralytic disease that starts as a flu-like illness followed by neurologic symptoms due to the afﬁnity of the virus for the acetylcholine receptors in the brain, which include hydrophobia, seizures, disorientation, hallucination. coma, and death. Diagnosis is made clinically, but in cases of a lethal outcome-autopsies will show the so-called Negri bodies or Intracytoplasmic inclusion bodies.

choices.text: Type IV, mediated by CD4+ T cells.
Type II, mediated by CD4+ T cells.
Type I, mediated by IgE antibodies.
Type III, mediated by IgG antibodies.

questions.text: A 31-year-old woman presents to her primary care provider to discuss the results from a previous urine analysis. She has no new complaints and feels well. Past medical history is signiﬁcant for systemic lupus erythematosus. She was diagnosed 5 years ago and takes hydroxychloroquine every day and prednisone when her condition ﬂares. Her previous urine analysis shows elevated protein levels (4+) and blood (3+). The urine sediment contained red blood cells (6 RBCs/high-power ﬁeld). The treating physician would like to perform a renal biopsy to rule out lupus nephritis. What type of hypersensitivity is suggestive of lupus nephritis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Type III, mediated by IgG antibodies.

•    This patient, with a known history of systemic lupus Erythematosus (SLE) is likely suffering from lupus nephritis. Immune complexes form in the blood and deposit in the glomerular basement membrane, stimulating an immune response. This is most consistent with a a type III hypersensitivity reaction. 

•    Type ill hypersensitivity reactions occur when antibodies bind to antigens and form soluble antigen-antibody complexes precipitate out of the blood and are deposited in various tissues throughout the body. These immune complexes stimulate an inﬂammation reaction at the site of deposition. The antigens may exogenous or endogenous as in this case of systemic lupus erythematosus. 

•    Another classic type III hypersensitivity reaction is the Arthus reaction. Immune complexes form and become deposited in the area of vaccination in a previously sensitized patient. This causes a local vasculitis with redness and induration. within hours of injection.

questions.text: A 66-year-old farmer is being evaluated for abnormal lung ﬁndings on a low dose chest CT scan obtained as part of his lung cancer screening. He has a 50-pack /year smoking history and has been hesitant to quit. He has a non-productive cough but brushes it away saying he is not bothered by it. He denies ever coughing up blood, breathlessness, chest pain, fatigue, or weight loss. He has never sought any medical care and states that he has always been in good shape. He consumes alcohol moderately and uses marijuana occasionally. He lives with his wife and has not traveled recently. On physical examination, his temperature is 37.1°C), blood pressure is 148/70 mm Hg, and pulse rate is 95/mm. General physical examination is unremarkable. Coarse breath sounds are present bilaterally. The cardiac exam is normal. Laboratory studies show a normal complete blood count and comprehensive metabolic panel. A follow-up high resolution CT scan is performed that shows small irregular sub centimeter pulmonary nodules, several of which are cavitated in both lungs, predominantly distributed in the upper and middle zones. There is no mediastinal or hilar lymphadenopathy. A transbronchial needle aspiration of the lesion is performed which shows a nodular pattern of abundant, granular, mildly eosinophilic cells with grooved nuclei with indented nuclear membranes and a chronic inﬂammation that consists primarily of eosinophils. immunohistochemical staining reveals numerous cells that stain positive for S100 and CD1a. Which of the cells of the human immune system are responsible for this lesion?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Dendritic cells

•    This patient has pulmonary Langerhans cell histiocytosis (PLCH). Langerhans cell histiocytosis is a rare disease caused by a proliferation of Langerhans cells, dendritic cells normally found in the skin and some mucosa. 

•    They are antigen-presenting cells. Langerhans cell histiocytosis can affect any organ but is more commonly found in bone, lymph nodes or skin. 

•    Symptoms include bone swelling, a scaly erythematous rash of the skin or lymph node enlargement. These can form a single nodule {unifocal} or many nodules (multifocal). When these proliferations involve the lung it is called pulmonary Langerhans cell histiocytosis (PLCHJ. 

•    PLCH has a strong association with smoking. At this time, the pathophysiology is unknown. The process of developing these nodules of Langerhans cells may be reactive or neoplastic. 

•    PLCH can be found incidentally or due to a chronic cough associated with the disease. The typical pathological lesion observed in PLCH is a ﬁbrotic nodule, a granuloma centered around the distal bronchioles and composed of Langerhans cells, plasma cells, fibroblasts, and alveolar macrophages.

questions.text: A 30-year-old woman seeks evaluation at a clinic complaining of shaking, chills, fevers, and headaches for the last 3 days. There is no history of toss of consciousness or respiratory distress. The vital signs include: temperature 38.3°C , respiratory rate 19/mm, blood pressure 120/80 mm Hg and pulse 94/min (rapid and thread). On general examination, she is pale and the sclera are jaundiced. The laboratory ﬁndings are as follows: Hct – 30%,  Total bilirubin : 2.6 mg/dL , Direct bilirubin :0.3 mg/dL. A peripheral smear is shown below. What is the most severe complication of this condition?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Cerebral edema

•    The patient has a Plasmodium falciparum infection. Approximately one—half of the global population is at risk for malaria.  

•    Malaria classically presents with paroxysms of fevers with chills and rigors. The malarial paroxysm coincides with the release of merozoites from ruptured erythrocytes. Headaches, jaundice, anemia, splenomegaly, and hepatomegaly are other signs and symptoms of malaria. 

•    Additionally, the unconjugated bilirubin level will be elevated as the red blood cells rupture during the maturation process of the parasite.

•    Main complication is cerebral malaria. Patients with cerebral edema can present with irritability, seizures. and coma.

questions.text: A 44-year-old man presents to a clinic for evaluation of difficulty swallowing for the past few days. He says that he has noticed progressively worsening chest pain when he attempts to swallow solids or liquids. He works from a home ofﬁce, has not had any recent sick contacts, and is not currently sexually active. His medical history includes acquired immunodeﬁciency syndrome. He is under HAART. The temperature is 100.6°F, the pulse is 72/min, respirations are 18/min, and the blood pressure is 136/84 mm Hg. The physical examination is notable for a dry mouth with red mucosa and no distinct plaques or patches, and a supple neck with no masses or cervical lymphadenopathy. An esophagogastroduodenoscopy shows small white patches within the oesophageal lumen. A biopsy of one of the lesions is performed and the microscopic appearance of the ﬁnding is shown below. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Oesophageal candidiasis

•    The majority of esophageal candidiasis cases are caused by Candida albicans and occur in immunocompromised patients, such as those who are taking steroids, undergoing chemotherapy, or who are positive with CD4T -cell counts < 100 cells/microliter. 

•    Although oropharyngeal candidiasis, also called thrush, is the most common opportunistic infection in HIV-positive individuals, absence of oropharyngeal candidiasis does not preclude the possibility that the infection is present within the esophagus. When the infection is limited to the oropharynx, where candidiasis can be differentiated from leucoplakia by the ease with which the patch or plaque can be scraped off with a tongue blade (budding yeasts with pseudohyphae are seen on Microscopic examination], and can be treated with non-absorbable topical antifungals. such as nystatin (a liquid suspension that patients can be taught to ‘swish and swallow“). 

•    Because esophageal candidiasis is considered more invasive, systemic antifungal treatment (typically fluconazole, for 14-21 days) is required.

questions.text: A 40-year-old farmer seeks evaluation at a clinic with complaints of a chronic cough, fevers, and anorexia of several months duration. On examination, he has generalized lymphadenopathy with hepatosplenomegaly. A chest radiograph reveals local inﬁltrates and patchy opacities involving all lung ﬁelds. Fine needle aspiration of an enlarged lymph node shows the presence of intracellular yeast. A fungal culture shows the presence of thick—walled spherical spores with tubercles and microconidia. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Histoplasmosis

•    Of the listed signs and symptoms, the patient is most likely to have histoplasmosis. 

•    Histoplasmosis is caused by spores generally found in bird droppings.

•    Histoplasmosis presents as a cough, fevers, anemia, lymphadenopathy, and hepatosplenomegaly with a high fatality rate. 

•    A lymph node aspiration showed the presence of intracellular yeast, which facilitates the diagnosis of fungi. 

•    Thick-walled spherical spores with tubercles and microconidia are typical diagnostic features of histoplasmosis.

questions.text: You are working as a resident in COVID 19 intensive care unit with wearing appropriate PPE. As per the current govt biomedical norms regarding COVID19, the image shown here is discarded in which color coded bin?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Red

As per the current Govt Guidelines, Infected plastics should be segregated /discarded in Red color bin.

choices.text: Fetal exsanguination after rupture of the membranes

questions.text: A 22-year-old G1P0 at 28 weeks gestation by LMP presents to labor and delivery complaining of decreased fetal movement. She has had no prenatal care. On the fetal monitor there are no contractions. The fetal heart rate is 150 beats per minute and reactive. An ultrasound is performed in the radiology department and shows a 28-week fetus with normal-appearing anatomy and size consistent with dates. The placenta is implanted on the posterior uterine wall and its margin is well away from the cervix. A succenturiate lobe of the placenta is seen implanted low on the anterior wall of the uterus. This patient is most at risk for which of the following?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

This patient has a succenturiate lobe which will be attached to main lobe and is likely that the vessels will traverse the internal os while connecting two lobes which is  vasa previa. When fetal vessels cross the internal os (vasa previa), rupture of membranes may be accompanied by rupture of a fetal vessel leading to fetal exsanguination. Vasa previa does not increase the risk for placenta accreta or amniotic fluid embolism. With velamentous insertion of the cord, the umbilical vessels separate in the membranes at a distance from the placental margin which they reach surrounded only by amnion. Such insertion occurs in about 1% of singleton gestations but is quite common in multiple pregnancies. Fetal malformations are more common with velamentous insertion of the umbilical cord. An increased risk of premature rupture of membranes and of torsion of the umbilical cord has not been described in association with velamentous insertion of the cord.

questions.text: A 21-year-old woman presents with left lower quadrant pain. An anterior 7-cm ﬁrm adnexal mass is palpated. She undergoes cystectomy and the following is the tumour seen. What percentage of these tumors are bilateral?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

This is dermoid and is a germ cell tumour of the ovary. Germ cell tumours are unilateral

The risk of bilaterality in dermoid is upto 10%. It is a benign tumour and risk of malignancy is 0.2-2% if it develops a malignancy it  is likely to be in the area of Rokitansky protruberance and is most commonly squamous c ell cancer. It is the most common ovarian tumour in reproductive age group and most common ovarian tumour to undergo torsion.

choices.text: The patient likely has constipation related to her pregnancy and should be dis charged with reassurance and instructions to give herself a enema and follow a high-fiber diet with laxative use as needed.
The patient likely has appendicitis and should be prepped for the operating room immediately to have an emergent appendectomy.
The patient should be sent to radiology for an upright abdominal x-ray.
The patient likely has hyperemesis gravidarum and intravenous antiemetics should be administered to the patient.

questions.text: A 32-year-old G2P0101 at 20 weeks gestational age presents to the emergency room complaining of constipation and abdominal pain for the past 48 hours. The patient also admits to nausea and vomiting since the evening before. The emergency room doctor who examines the patient calls you and reports that the patient has low-grade fever of 37.7°C (100°F), with a normal pulse and blood pressure. The patient’s abdomen is distended and mildly tender to palpation in all quadrants with high-pitched bowel sounds. She has no rebound tenderness. The patient’s WBC is 13,000, and her electrolytes are normal. You recommend which of the following as the most appropriate next step in the management of this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

This patient’s history and physical examination are consistent with an intestinal obstruction. An intestinal obstruction must be ruled out because, if it goes undiagnosed and untreated, it can result in a bowel perforation. Common symptoms of intestinal obstruction include colicky abdominal pain, nausea, and emesis. Signs of a bowel obstruction include abdominal tenderness and increased or decreased bowel sounds–depending on the duration of the obstruction. Fever and an elevated white blood cell count are present with bowel strangulation and necrosis. This patient has a mild leukocytosis, which is also characteristic of normal pregnancy. In order to rule out an intestinal obstruction, an upright or lateral decubitus abdominal x-ray should be done to identify the presence of distended loops of bowel and air-fluid levels which confirm the diagnosis

questions.text: A 42-year-old G4P3104 presents for her well-woman examination. She states her cycles are regular and denies any sexually transmitted diseases. Currently she and her husband use condoms, but they hate the hassle of a coital-dependent method. She is interested in a more effective contraception because they do not want any more children. She reports occasional migraine headache and smokes occasionally. She weighs 78 kg, and her blood pressure is 142/89 mm Hg. During her office visit, you counsel the patient at length regarding birth control methods. Which of the following is the most appropriate contraceptive method for this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

An intrauterine device is a highly effective long-term method for which the patient has no contraindication. The patient’s smoking and age contraindicate the use of combination oral contraceptives. Migraine headaches accompanied by neurologic symptoms such as loss of vision, paresthesias, and numbness are generally considered to be a contraindication to combination oral contraceptive use. Use of a diaphragm is a coital-dependent action and the patient relates that it is not something she desires.

questions.text: A 50-year-old woman is diagnosed with cervical cancer. Which lymph node group would be the first involved in metastatic spread of this disease beyond the cervix and uterus?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

The main routes of spread of cervical cancer include vaginal mucosa, myometrium, paracervical lymphatics, and direct extension into the parametrium. The prevalence of lymph node disease correlates with the stage of malignancy. Primary node groups involved in the spread of cervical cancer include the paracervical, parametrial, obturator, hypogastric, external iliac, and sacral nodes, essentially in that order. Less commonly, there is involvement in the common iliac, inguinal, and para-aortic nodes. In stage I, the pelvic nodes are positive in approximately 15% of cases and the para-aortic nodes in 6%. In stage II, pelvic nodes are positive in 28% of cases and para-aortic nodes in 16%. In stage III, pelvic nodes are positive in 47% of cases and para-aortic nodes in 28%.

questions.text: A 35-year-old woman Undergoes A sonogram at 12 weeks and shows the following. Which of the following is the next best advise for the patient for her evaluation
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

The most common association of raised NT is with trisomy 21, but it can also be seen with other trisomies like trisomy 18 and also with  monosomy X. 

 Raised nuchal translucency beyond 3 mm should therefore be offered diagnostic genetic studies. Offering prompt invasive testing shortens the time between positive screen and definitive diagnosis. 

Cell free fetal DNA can be an alternative if the patient wants to avoid invasive testing. But cell free fetal DNA testing is a screening test.

questions.text: In combination birth control pills, which of the following is the primary contraceptive effect of the estrogenic component?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

The main contraceptive efficacy of OCPs is suppression of ovulation by inhibition of GnRH from the hypothalamus as well as inhibition of LH and FSH and disruption of midcycle LH surge. These effects are mediated by both estrogen and progesterone but suppression of FSH and prevention of folliculogenesis is the most important mechanism. 

Additional progesterone related mechanism that contribute to contraceptive efficacy include making endometrium thin, thickening of cervical mucus and impairment of tubal motility and peristalsis.

questions.text: Match the columns with their correct usg parameter
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

The single best parameter for fetal growth is abdominal circumference. AC < 10th percentile is suggestive of IUGR while AC> 35cm is suggestive of macrosomia 

The best parameter for pregnancy dating is CRL ideally done between 7-10 weeks although it is used for pregnancy dating up to 14 weeks 

Level 2 usg can be done between 18-22 weeks it is the single most important usg to be done during pregnancy 

Amniocentesis should be done at and beyond 15 weeks as Early amniocentesis done between 11-14 weeks has higher risk of fetal loss

Placenta which is in lower uterine segment in early pregnancy should be reviewed at 32 weeks as most placenta will show migration to the upper segment due to differential growth of the uterus.

choices.text: Perform a cone biopsy of the cervix
Repeat the Pap smear to obtain endocervical cells
Perform colposcopy and directed cervical biopsies
Order HPV typing on the initial Pap smear

questions.text: A 22-year-old woman presents for her first Pap smear. She has been sexually active with only one boyfriend since age 19. Her physical examination is completely normal. However, 2 weeks later her Pap smear results return showing HGSIL. There were no endocervical cells seen on the smear. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in the management of this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Any patient with a Pap smear result that suggests dysplasia of the cervix should undergo colpos copy. The Pap smear is a cytological screening test for cervical neoplasm. In patients with an HGSIL Pap, there is no indication for repeating the smear or ordering HPV testing as the cytological test suggests the presence of cervical neoplasia. Repeating a Pap could produce a false-negative result, which can lead to a delay in treatment of the patient. Random cervical biopsies are not indicated because the actual abnormal tissue may be missed. The indications for a cone biopsy would be (1) unsatisfactory colpos copic examination (ie, the entire transformation zone cannot be seen); (2) a colpos copically directed cervical biopsy that indicates the possibility of invasive disease; (3) neoplasm in the endocervix; or (4) cells seen on cervical biopsy that do not adequately explain the cells seen on cytologic examination (ie, the Pap).

questions.text: A 29-year-old G0 comes to your office complaining of a vaginal dis charge for the past 2 weeks. The patient describes the discharge as thin in consistency and of a grayish white colour. She denies any vaginal or vulvar pruritus or burning. She admits to being sexually active in the past, but has not had intercourse during the past year On physical examination, the vulva appears normal. There is a dis charge present at the introitus.. The vaginal pH is 5.5. The cervix is not inflamed and there is no cervical discharge. Wet smear of the discharge is shown below . Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Bacterial vaginosis is a condition in which there is an overgrowth of anaerobic bacteria in the vagina, displacing the normal lactobacillus. Women with this type of vaginitis complain of an unpleasant vaginal odor that is described as musky or fishy and a thin, gray-white vaginal dis charge. Vulvar irritation and pruritus are rarely present. To confirm the diagnosis of bacterial vaginosis, a wet smear is done. To perform a wet smear, saline is mixed with the vaginal discharge and clue cells are identified. Clue cells are vaginal epithelial cells with clusters of bacteria adherent to their surfaces. In addition, a whiff test can be performed by mixing potassium hydroxide with the vaginal dis charge. In cases of bacterial vaginosis, an amine-like (ie, fishlike) odor will be detected. The treatment of choice for bacterial vaginosis is metronidazole (Flagyl) 500 mg given twice daily for 7 days. Pregnant women with symptomatic bacterial vaginosis (BV) should be treated the same way as nonpregnant women with BV. In cases of a normal or physiologic discharge, vaginal secretions are white and odorless. In addition, normal vaginal secretions do not adhere to the vaginal side walls.

choices.text: Schedule an amniocentesis for amniotic fluid bilirubin at 16 weeks.
Schedule Percutaneous Umbilical Blood Sampling (PUBS) to determine fetal hematocrit at 20 weeks.

questions.text: A 38-year-old G1P1 comes to see you for her first prenatal visit at 12 weeks gestational age. She had a previous term vaginal delivery without any complications. You detect fetal heart tones at this visit, and her uterine size is consistent with dates. Two weeks later, the results of the patient’s prenatal labs come back. Her blood type is A–, with an anti-D antibody titer of 1:16. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in the management of this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Once the antibody screen is positive for isoimmunization, the after should be followed at regular intervals (about every 4 weeks). A titer of 1:16 or greater is usually indicative of the possibility of severe hemolytic disease of the fetus. Once the critical titer is reached, further evaluation is done by MCA Doppler to look for fetal anaemia. If MCA doppler peak systolic velocity is more than 1.5 MOM then we must plan for Cordocentesis, or percutaneous umbilical blood sampling, involves obtaining a blood sample from the umbilical cord under ultrasound guidance. The fetal blood sample can then be analyzed for Hct and determination of fetal blood type. Cordocentesis also allows the fetus with anemia to undergo a blood transfusion.

questions.text: Match the columns with relevant embryologically correct statements
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Epoophoron paroophoron aNd gartners are remnants of mesonephric duct or wolffian duct while appendix of testes is remnant of mullerian in males

Ovary and testes arise from genital ridge 

While clitoris is derived from genital tubercle, the male homologous organ is penis

questions.text: While evaluating a 30-year-old woman for infertility, you diagnose the following . You explain that additional testing is necessary because of the woman’s increased risk of congenital anomalies in which organ system?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

This is unicornuate uterus This condition is associated with a higher risk of obstetric complications, such as an increase in the rate of second-trimester abortion and premature labor. If these pregnancies go to term, malpresentations such as breech and transverse lie are more frequentAn intravenous pyelogram or urinary tract ultrasound is mandatory in patients with Müllerian anomalies since approximately 30% of patients with Müllerian anomalies have coexisting congenital urinary tract anomalies.

questions.text: A primigravida at 32 weeks comes to emergency department because of heavy vaginal bleeding and abdominal pain. Her prenatal course was unremarkable including 20 week usg. Examination shows a contracted uterus with hypertonus. A large gush of blood occurs during cervical examination which shows a long closed cervix. The FHR shows severe late deceleartions. Which of the following is most appropriate next step in management
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

The patient has a classic triad of placental abruption which is third trimester bleeding with hypertonus with fetal distress. This patient has abruption with fetal distress with closed cervix tocolytics are contraindicated in abruption, oxytocin has no role in this patient as the os is closed and unfavourable.

questions.text: A 34-year-old woman p2l2 comes to the physician because of vaginal bleeding, Her last menstrual period was 8 weeks ago, and a home pregnancy test 2 weeks ago was positive. She has had mild uterine cramping but is otherwise asymptomatic. Pelvic examination reveals a 12-14 week, nontender uterus. The remainder of the physical examination is unremarkable. Urine hCG is positive, Pelvic ultrasound reveals the following. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

This is an usg image showing snowstorm appearance which is characteristic to complete mole, no fetus is seen. The treatment of choice is suction evacuation but preoperatively serum HCG evaluation is mandatory so that follow up can be done also decision for prophylactic chemotherapy is dependent on serum HCG levels. Hysterectomy is an alternative for patients who have completed child bearing and have high risk factors for GTN that is uterine size greater than gestational age, HCG>100000 ovarian theca lutein cyst and age more than 40 years .

questions.text: A 22-year-old woman consults you for treatment of hirsutism. She is obese and has facial acne and hirsutism and periareolar regions and a male escutcheon. Serum LH level is 35 mIU/mL and FSH is 9 mIU/mL. Androstenedione and testosterone levels are mildly elevated, but serum DHEAS is normal. The following is the ultrasound image obtained. Which of the following single agents is the most appropriate treatment of her condition?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

This patient meets the rotterdams  criteria for PCOS, her amin complaints is hirsutism 

The drug of choice for PCOS is OCPs they are also first line drug for hirsutism due to PCOS 

Low dose OCPs are preferred. If the patient is not satisfied with clinical response to OCP monotherapy at 6 months the spironolactone is added. Other antiandrogens that can be added are cyproterone acetate, flutamide and finasteride.

questions.text: You suspect that your infertility patient has an inadequate luteal phase. She should undergo an endometrial biopsy on which day of her menstrual cycle?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

The diagnostic evaluation of an infertile couple should be thorough and completed as rapidly as possible. The primary diagnostic steps in the workup of the infertile couple include (1) documentation of ovulation by measurement of basal body temperature (BBT) or mid-luteal phase serum progesterone; (2) semen analysis; (3) postcoital test; (4) hysterosalpingogram; and (5) endometrial biopsy. Women should record their BBT for evidence of ovulation. In addition, serial serum progesterone levels may be helpful to confirm ovulation. Serum progesterone values should be obtained 7 days after ovulation, around day 21, and may also be helpful in evaluating inadequate luteal phase. An endometrial biopsy may also provide valuable information regarding the status of the luteal phase. The biopsy is obtained 12 days after the thermogenic shift, or 2 to 3 days before the expected onset of menses, about day 26 of a 28-day cycle.

questions.text: All the following structures can be held with the instrument shown except ?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

This is babcock  forcep and is used to hold luminal structures. It is not used to hold abdominal wall.

choices.text: Continue to wait and observe the patient.

questions.text: A 25-year-old G3P2 at 39 weeks is admitted in labor at 6cm dilated. The fetal heart rate tracing is reactive. Two hours later, she is reexamined and her cervix is unchanged at 6 cm dilated. An IUPC is placed and the patient is noted to have 280 Montevideo units (MUV) by the IUPC. After an additional 2 hours of labor, the patient is noted to still be 6cm dilated. The fetal heart rate tracing remains reactive. Which of the following is the best next step in the management of this labor?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

The patient is having adequate uterine contractions as determined by the intrauterine pressure catheter. Therefore, augmentation with Pitocin is not indicated. The patient’s diagnosis is secondary arrest of labor, which requires cesarean section. In the active phase of labor, a multiparous patient should undergo dilation of the cervix at a rate of at least 1.5 cm/h if uterine contractions are adequate. There is no indication for the use of vacuum or forceps in this patient because the patient’s cervix is not completely dilated and the head is unengaged. Assisted vaginal delivery with vacuum or forceps is indicated when the patient is completely dilated, to augment maternal pushing when maternal expulsive efforts are insufficient to deliver the fetus. It is not recommended to continue to allow the patient to labor if dystocia is diagnosed, because uterine rupture is a potential complication.

questions.text: You are delivering a 33-year-old G3P2 and encounter a shoulder dystocia. After performing the appropriate maneuvers, the baby finally delivers, and the paediatricians attending the delivery note the following . Which of the following is the baby’s most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Shoulder dystocias can be associated with significant fetal morbidity including brachial plexus palsies, clavicular fractures, and humeral fractures. Fractures of the clavicle and humerus usually heal rapidly and are clinically insignificant. Injury to the brachial plexus may be localized to the upper or lower roots. In Erb (or Erb-Duchenne) palsy, the upper roots of the brachial plexus are injured (C5-6), resulting in paralysis of the shoulder and arm muscles; the arm hangs limply to the side and is extended and internally rotated. In the case of Klumpke paralysis, the lower nerves of the brachial plexus are affected (C7-T1) and the hand is paralyzed.

questions.text: The following fetal position is seen in which type of maternal pelvis
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

This is ROP position. Most common cause of occipeto posterior position is android pelvis while the pelvis associated with  persistent OP and direct OP is anthropoid pelvis 

Platypelloid pelvis is associated with face and brow presentation.

questions.text: A 50 year old woman presents with intermenstrual bleeding for last 6 months, bleeding is not very heavy. A transvaginal ultrasound is done which shows the following image . What is then likely diagnosis of this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

The ultrasound image shows smooth growth in the cavity of uterus which shows feeder vessel on doppler. It is characteristic of endometrial polyp, it is associated with irregular bleeding or intermenstrual bleeding. The inestigation of choice is hysteroscopy and treatment is hysteroscopic polypectomy.

questions.text: A 76-year-old woman presents for evaluation of urinary incontinence. She had a hysterectomy for fibroid tumors of the uterus at age 48. After complete evaluation, you determine that the patoent has genuine stress urinary incontinence. On physical examination, she has a hypermobile urethra, but there is no cystocele or rectocele. Which of the following surgical procedures should you recommend to this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

A midurethral sling procedure such as the transobturator tape or transvaginal tape placement would be the most appropriate surgical treatment for stress urinary incontinence in this patient. Kelly plication is an older procedure used to suspend the urethra and has a lower cure rate for stress incontinence than the Burch procedure. The Burch procedure suspends the bladder neck to Cooper ligament of the pubic bone using an abdominal approach. Anterior and posterior colporrhaphy are procedures used to correct cystoceles and rectoceles and are not indicated in this patient. Sacral colpopexy is a procedure to repair prolapse of the vagina by suspending the vaginal vault from the sacrum. The midurethral sling procedures are minimally invasive requiring only small vaginal and skin incisions. Additionally they may be performed as an outpatient procedure.

choices.text: Apply an ice pack to the perineum.
Place a vaginal pack for 24 hours

questions.text: You performed a forceps-assisted vaginal delivery on a 20-year-old G1 at 40 weeks for maternal exhaustion.. A second-degree episiotomy was cut to facilitate delivery. Eight hours after delivery, you are called to see the patient because she is unable to void and complains of severe pain. On examination the following is seen. What is the best management for this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

The history and image are characteristic of vulval hematoma, it presents as pain and local examination shows a bluish tender swelling. Most hematomas are managed expectantly with monitoring and application of ice packs and analgesics but hematoma associated with sever pain or expanding in size or associated with unstable vitals needs to undergo surgical evacuation.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a cause of ambiguous genitalia in female child
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

5 alpha reductase deficiency will cause ambiguous genitalia in a genetic male and not genetic female 

Other causes of atypical genitalia in XY karyotype are 

SRY related gonadal dysgenesis 

SOX 9 mutation

WNT4 overexpression

17 beta OH steroid dehydrogenase 

3beta OH steroid dehydrogenase

Partial AIS

questions.text: A young woman complains of headache. On examination, the vision is 6/6 with normal pupillary reactions. She has bitemporal field defects on confrontation visual field examination. Other visual field testing was also done. The doctor has a presumptive diagnosis in mind and he wanted to get a definitive imaging for the etiology. He got the imaging as shown in the picture. Endocrinological evaluation was also done when she was sent to an endocrinologist.
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

T1-weighted gadolinium-enhanced MR of a pituitary adenoma, affecting optic chiasma

When nerve fibre loss is confined to fibres originating in the nasal retina, only the nasal and temporal aspects of the disc will be involved, resulting in a band or ‘bow tie’-shaped atrophy. Both congruous and incongruous visual field defects can be seen in chiasmal lesions.

Optic disc drusen is not a feature of chiasmal involvement

choices.text: Initiate amblyopia management with patching or pharmacologic agents
Neuroimaging to further evaluate decreased vision

questions.text: A 6-year-old female fails a school vision screen. Her vision is 6/60 OD and 6/6 OS. According to school policies, her parents were asked to see an ophthalmologist. Her anterior and posterior segment examinations are within normal limits. On alternate cover test, there was esophoria. Refraction with 1% atropine was +5.00 sphere OD and +2.50 sphere OS. What is the most appropriate next step?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)
 
This patient has anisometropic amblyopia. The first line of treatment is to provide optical correction, as a significant number of patients will have vision improvement with glasses alone.

choices.text: Orbital decompression, Squint surgery, Eyelid surgery
